title: 112_s235
content: S. 235 introduced in the Senate aims to provide personal jurisdiction in causes of action against contractors of the United States performing contracts abroad with respect to members of the Armed Forces, civilian employees of the United States, and United States citizen employees of companies working for the United States in connection with contractor activities. Mrs. McCaskill introduced a bill in the Senate to provide personal jurisdiction in causes of action against contractors of the United States performing contracts abroad with respect to members of the Armed Forces, civilian employees, and US citizen employees of companies working for the US. The bill is titled the "Lieutenant Colonel Dominic 'Rocky' Baragona Justice for American Heroes Harmed by Contractors Act". SEC. 2. Debarment or suspension of US government contractors for evasion of process or failure to appear in actions related to government contracts. The Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council must amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation to allow for the debarment or suspension of a contractor with the US government if they evade service of process or fail to appear in court for actions related to government contracts. The amendments to the Federal Acquisition Regulation allow for the debarment or suspension of a contractor for not fulfilling contract obligations. The amendments apply to contractor actions after the effective date and do not limit a contractor's rights under the Constitution. SEC. 3. Personal jurisdiction in covered civil actions by members of the armed forces, civilian employees of the United States, and United States citizen employees of companies performing work for the United States against entities under United States government contracts performed abroad. The Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council must amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation to require consent to personal jurisdiction in covered contracts for civil actions, including actions against contractor employees. Consent does not affect jurisdiction in other courts. The Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council mandates consent to personal jurisdiction in covered contracts for civil actions, including those where events occurred outside the US and jurisdiction cannot be established in another Federal court. Contractors without a US office must designate a US agent for service of process in such actions. The Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council requires that covered civil actions be analyzed according to US laws, with the substantive law of the State where the action is brought applying if the events occurred in a hazardous duty zone designated by the Secretary of Defense. The amendments to the Federal Acquisition Regulation apply to all relevant contracts. Regulation made under subsection (a) applies to covered contracts entered into after the effective date of the amendments under subsection (a). SEC. 4. Personal jurisdiction for actions brought by the United States government alleging wrongdoing under U.S. government contracts performed abroad. The Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council must amend the Federal Acquisition Regulation to require contractors to consent to personal jurisdiction in Federal courts for any wrongdoing related to covered contracts. Consent does not affect jurisdiction in other courts. The Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council requires contractors to consent to personal jurisdiction in Federal courts for actions related to covered contracts, especially if the events occurred outside the US and personal jurisdiction cannot be established in another Federal court. Contractors without a US office must designate an agent in the US for service of process. These amendments apply to contracts entered into after the effective date. The amendments do not limit other jurisdictional bases for legal action against contractors. SEC. 5. SAVINGS CLAUSE. This Act does not limit any cause of action or remedy under other laws. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "contractor" includes the contractor, subcontractors, parent companies, and employees working on the contract. "Covered civil action" refers to lawsuits involving rape, sexual assault, or serious bodily injury to US Armed Forces members, civilian employees, or contractors under a US contract. A "covered contract" is a contract for work outside the US with a value of $5,000,000 or more, including subcontracts. "Rape" is defined as conduct violating a specific section of the Uniform Code of Military Justice. The term "serious bodily injury" is defined in section 1365 of title 18, US Code. "Sexual assault" refers to conduct that would violate specific sections of the Uniform Code of Military Justice. The term "United States" refers to the several States and the District of Columbia. The term "United States" includes the several States and the District of Columbia, excluding military installations or facilities outside this area.
